Award.AbstractNarration:
The main focus of the proposal is the investigation of several types of infinite structure, using a range of mathematical tools. A secondary focus is the investigation of problems about very large finite structures, using certain infinite "limit" structures. Some of the problems to be studied are "test questions" intended to stimulate the development of new idea and methods.

The topics of the proposal are mostly concerned with large cardinals, ZFC combinatorics (particularly of singular cardinals) and forcing. They include forcing axioms for successors of singulars, various forms of the tree property, connections between compactness properties, PCF theory and universality numbers. The last section of the proposal is concerned with problems arising in Razborov's theory of flag algebras.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to investigate infinite structures in mathematics. The structures of interest included graphs, orderings and trees. The project produced a substantial number of results, which were documented in eleven journal papers published or submitted since the project began. The project also afforded a number of training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, who worked with me on topics related to the main themes of the project. I lectured on my results at a number of national and international reserach conferences, and also gave several series of tutorial lectures aimed at novice researchers. During the project I collaborated with mathematicians from the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Austria, Israel and Iran.

Highlights of the project included:

-A family of results about infinite trees. The main motivating question was whether a tree which is "tall" (has many levels) and "skinny" (each level is small in comparison to the number of levels) must have a branch which meets every level. A related question asks whether if, given a point on each level of the tree, we may find a branch which passes through a substantial proportion of the selected points.

-Results about "singular cardinals", where a singular cardinal is an infinite set which can be broken into a strictly smaller number of strictly smaller pieces: the complementary notion of "regular cardinal" refers to sets that can not be broken upin this way. The results extend some known facts about regular cardinals to the (much harder) context of singular cardinals.

-Results about "Dowker filters" and "super-Dowker filters", which are exotic objects arising in the study of infinite spaces. The results include a much simpler construction than was previously known for a Dowker filter, and the first construction (at least in the standard context where we do mathematics) for a super-Dowker filter.


Last Modified: 09/06/2020
Modified by: James W Cummings
